label: neg
docAbstract:
Pursuant to sections 1031 and 1032 of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Public Law 111-203) (Dodd-Frank Act), the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (Bureau) is proposing to establish 12 CFR part 1041, which would contain regulations creating consumer protections for certain consumer credit products. The proposal generally would cover two categories of loans. First, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term of 45 days or less or loans with multiple advances if each advance is required to be repaid within 45 days. Second, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term greater than 45 days, provided that they (1) have an all-in annual percentage rate greater than 36 percent; and (2) either are repaid directly from the consumer’s account or income or are secured by the consumer’s vehicle. For both categories of covered loans, the proposal would identify it as an abusive and unfair practice for a lender to make a covered loan without reasonably determining that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal generally would require that, before making a covered loan, a lender must reasonably determine that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal also would impose certain restrictions on making covered loans when a consumer has or recently had certain an outstanding covered loan. The proposal would provide lenders with options to make covered loans without satisfying the ability-to-repay requirements, if those loans meet certain conditions. The proposal also would identify it as an unfair and abusive practice to attempt to withdraw payment from a consumer’s account for a
covered loan after two consecutive payment attempts have failed. The proposal would require lenders to provide certain notices to the consumer before attempting to withdraw payment for a
covered loan from the consumer’s account. The Bureau is also proposing to adopt official interpretations to the proposed regulation.

Pursuant to sections 1031 and 1032 of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Public Law 111-203) (Dodd-Frank Act), the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (Bureau) is proposing to establish 12 CFR part 1041, which would contain regulations creating consumer protections for certain consumer credit products. The proposal generally would cover two categories of loans. First, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term of 45 days or less or loans with multiple advances if each advance is required to be repaid within 45 days. Second, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term greater than 45 days, provided that they (1) have an all-in annual percentage rate greater than 36 percent; and (2) either are repaid directly from the consumer’s account or income or are secured by the consumer’s vehicle. For both categories of covered loans, the proposal would identify it as an abusive and unfair practice for a lender to make a covered loan without reasonably determining that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal generally would require that, before making a covered loan, a lender must reasonably determine that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal also would impose certain restrictions on making covered loans when a consumer has or recently had certain an outstanding covered loan. The proposal would provide lenders with options to make covered loans without satisfying the ability-to-repay requirements, if those loans meet certain conditions. The proposal also would identify it as an unfair and abusive practice to attempt to withdraw payment from a consumer’s account for a
covered loan after two consecutive payment attempts have failed. The proposal would require lenders to provide certain notices to the consumer before attempting to withdraw payment for a
covered loan from the consumer’s account. The Bureau is also proposing to adopt official interpretations to the proposed regulation.

Pursuant to sections 1031 and 1032 of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Public Law 111-203) (Dodd-Frank Act), the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (Bureau) is proposing to establish 12 CFR part 1041, which would contain regulations creating consumer protections for certain consumer credit products. The proposal generally would cover two categories of loans. First, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term of 45 days or less or loans with multiple advances if each advance is required to be repaid within 45 days. Second, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term greater than 45 days, provided that they (1) have an all-in annual percentage rate greater than 36 percent; and (2) either are repaid directly from the consumer’s account or income or are secured by the consumer’s vehicle. For both categories of covered loans, the proposal would identify it as an abusive and unfair practice for a lender to make a covered loan without reasonably determining that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal generally would require that, before making a covered loan, a lender must reasonably determine that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal also would impose certain restrictions on making covered loans when a consumer has or recently had certain an outstanding covered loan. The proposal would provide lenders with options to make covered loans without satisfying the ability-to-repay requirements, if those loans meet certain conditions. The proposal also would identify it as an unfair and abusive practice to attempt to withdraw payment from a consumer’s account for a
covered loan after two consecutive payment attempts have failed. The proposal would require lenders to provide certain notices to the consumer before attempting to withdraw payment for a
covered loan from the consumer’s account. The Bureau is also proposing to adopt official interpretations to the proposed regulation.

Second, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term greater than 45 days, provided that they (1) have an all-in annual percentage rate greater than 36 percent; and (2) either are repaid directly from the consumer’s account or income or are secured by the consumer’s vehicle. For both categories of covered loans, the proposal would identify it as an abusive and unfair practice for a lender to make a covered loan without reasonably determining that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal generally would require that, before making a covered loan, a lender must reasonably determine that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal also would impose certain restrictions on making covered loans when a consumer has or recently had certain an outstanding covered loan. The proposal would provide lenders with options to make covered loans without satisfying the ability-to-repay requirements, if those loans meet certain conditions. The proposal also would identify it as an unfair and abusive practice to attempt to withdraw payment from a consumer’s account for a
covered loan after two consecutive payment attempts have failed. The proposal would require lenders to provide certain notices to the consumer before attempting to withdraw payment for a
covered loan from the consumer’s account. The Bureau is also proposing to adopt official interpretations to the proposed regulation.

text:
As an indoor tanning client who uses sunbeds in a professional salon, I strongly oppose the FDA's proposal to limit my indoor tanning sessions. I am well aware of the risks of UV overexposure, as is virtually everyone in America today. This topic gets more coverage than almost any other health issue.

I am also aware that the World Health Organization in 2015 placed bacon on the list of Level 1 carcinogens in the same category as a sunbed. WHO and the government's response to bacon's listing as a carcinogen was simply to warn people to use common sense and exercise judgment. The government did NOT step in and limit bacon consumption.

To my knowledge, there is no precedent where the federal government has put limits on consumer consumption for anything including alcohol and tobacco. Since indoor tanning carries a much smaller health risk than tobacco, how can limits on indoor tanning be justified?

Please work with the indoor tanning industry to develop standards that help prevent sunburn, but do not limit my ability, properly advised, to make choices about UV exposure in a professional salon for me or for any member of my family.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Docket Status: OPEN

text: I appreciate your stance and the direction where the FDA is coming from in regards to the new proposed limitations to tanning. However, I do have a right to do with my body as I please... and as many of us that use tanning beds do so to help cope with SAD and use it for light therapy, I am disappointed and frustrated that I am being forced away from a treatment that has helped me considerably in Wisconsin's winters.

text:
Docket No. FDA-1998-N0880

Sunlamp Products: Proposed Amendment to Performance Standard

As the owner of a professional tanning facility, I am submitting these comments in conjunction with material provided by the American Suntanning Association. I am concerned that, based on my experience, many of these proposals as written will not reduce sunburn incidence nor optimize exposure levels for my clients. Specifically:

FDA 21CFR 1040.20(d)(1)(iv) introduces an entirely new approach for a Manufacturer-Recommended Exposure Schedule. I have several concerns with this:

(1) FDA's proposed "Manufacturer-Recommended Exposure Schedule" needs revision. This system is supposed to provide a recommend framework leading to an absolute maximum time (the Maximum Timer Interval) to incrementally expose a tanner gradually. I could not in good faith recommend the series of intervals FDA proposes to my clients, which call for 3-4 minute increases from one session to the next - larger incremental increases than what I would ever routinely allow a client and for which FDA has no data in an actual salon tanning unit.

(2) Eliminating skin types from the schedule is a mistake. FDA asserts, "Skin Type III and IV can attain a tan with UV doses that are similar to what is needed for Skin Type II" based on a small study done with non-salon equipment in FDA's lab (Miller et al, 2012). While FDA's effort appears to be in good faith, based on my professional experience with thousands of tanning clients, FDA's conclusion is false. FDA did not even test Type IV tanners in its study. What's more, teaching clients their Fitzpatrick Skin Type is critical in my business to teach clients how to prevent sunburn both in the salon and outdoors. For clients with Skin Type II it may take several sessions before they see any results (which FDA expressed it wants clients to understand, per proposed 1040.20(5)(D)5). Taking this tool away will hurt my ability to teach Skin Type II sunbed clients how to prevent sunburn.

(3) Tanning courses and session frequency recommendations need revision. FDA's introduction of a "tanning course" ("the period of time over which a tan is developed" which FDA says is typically 3-4 weeks) and the suggestion that two sessions weekly should be a maximum fails to take into account why and how most indoor tanning clients visit salons and how professional salons teach and achieve sunburn prevention.

(a) A client who establishes a tan and then maintains it would not be engaging in a new "course." Almost no client starts, stops and starts tanning as a "course" six times in a year. Most tan about three sessions a week for four weeks, and then maintain their tan with differing frequency based on their skin type.

(b) Limiting a client to two sessions weekly will result in clients visiting more than one salon to get 3-4 sessions weekly or simply purchasing home tanning units, which FDA knows are associated with greater sunburn risk, both of which would increase variables between exposures and increase sunburn. It will also lead to clients requesting longer exposure times to compensate for having fewer visits, which is counterproductive to teaching gradual exposure and sunburn prevention.

(c) Instead of recommending 48 hours between sessions on the label, I suggest this recommendation: "Allow 24-48 hours between sessions to prevent sunburn." That gives the sunbed user and a salon operator the information they need to properly space sessions to prevent sunburn.

(d) Recommending a maximum of 48-50 sessions (15kJ) per year isn't warranted. There is no real metric for how you have established this. The government does not limit bacon or tobacco consumption for those who choose to consume those products - both of which present larger risks than sunbeds. I suggest the following: A statement on the exposure schedule that says, "Limit Your Total Exposure. UV overexposure is linked to skin cancer."

(4) FDA should not require salons to recertify equipment currently in the marketplace to comply with the new Performance Standard. This would be more costly than FDA estimates and would likely shutter my business.

Without the changes I have suggested, the combined economic impact of FDA's proposals as written would not prevent sunburn nor reduce exposure, but would eliminate more than 40 percent of my salon's total revenue and would not educate clients in an effective fashion. Combined with FDA Rule FDA-2015-N01765, these rules would eliminate 47-50 percent of my salon's revenue - which would close my business.

Please allow the American Suntanning Association and industry suppliers to work with you to improve your proposals.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Docket Status: OPEN

text: We have been in the process of adopting for 4+ years from Haiti and have found the process to be most difficult. As we visited Haiti on our socialization visit for our daughter, we were informed by the creche that adoptions in other countries are expedited more efficiently. Kids are leaving Haiti to go to Europe, but as far as the US, its rare. This is very discouraging. The restrictions and regulations that the US puts on developing countries makes it near impossible. As a pastor, I am grateful for what our country represents. Our country has a long history of care and compassion for the orphan and widow. However, in recent years, I have found the bureaucracy surrounding adoption to be insolvent and, well, very unamerican. I am grieved as how your attempt to make the system better actually makes it more complicated for Haiti and agencies operating in Haiti to convey adoptions. Where my citizenship used to afford me many freedoms, it now, in terms of adoption, is a liability. Please consider how your overthinking of adoption processes actually complicates and prevents adoption. You have many citizens who are looking to you for leadership. Please do not move forward with this rule change. It is detrimental to those you represent and the orphans that they are trying to bring home.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: The Department of State (the Department) proposes to amend requirements for accreditation of agencies and approval of persons to provide adoption services in intercountry adoption cases.  The proposed rule includes a new subpart establishing parameters for U.S. accrediting entities to authorize adoption service providers who  have received accreditation or approval to provide adoption services in countries designated by the Secretary which will be known as “country-specific authorization” (CSA).   Adoption service providers will only be permitted to act as primary providers in a CSA-designated country if they have received CSA for that particular country.  The proposed rule also strengthens certain standards for accreditation and approval including those related to fees and the use of foreign providers.  In addition, the proposed rule enhances standards relating to preparation of prospective adoptive parents so that they receive more training related to the most common challenges faced by adoptive families, and are better prepared for the needs of the specific child they are adopting.  These proposed changes are intended to align the preparation of prospective adoptive parents with the current demographics of children immigrating to the United States through intercountry adoption.   Finally, the proposed rule makes the mechanism to submit complaints about adoption service providers available to complainants even if they have not first addressed their complaint directly with the adoption service provider.

text: Feral cats are not vermin as they do provide real vermin control.  I am not sure that rats are vermin either but I do know that they have the potential to spread serious illness.  The possibility of cruel treatment Oslo cats will certainly increase is they are classified as vermin.  There are many trap, neuter and return programs available to humanely keep the number of feral cats under control.  CALOSHA would better serve the community by being a part of the solution by advocating these programs rather than adding to the problem by advocating widespread torture and killing of helpless animals.

label: pos

text:
Throughout the area I live in (southeastern PA) and in the area surrounding the sanctuary for which I volunteer (Ringoes, NJ), TNVR programs have contributed to the health and safety of community ("feral") cats and to the emotional health of the people that care for them. More to the point, though, is that the population of rodents has dropped significantly. The evidence on which I base this statement is, of course, from observation and others' anecdotes (their observations), not a controlled study. However, the problems we once had with mice and voles have diminished pretty drastically. As one of my neighbors said, if you get rid of the cats, you'll need a pied piper to get rid of the rodents that are now free to party.

My understanding is that many shipyard employers and their employees value the cats both for companionship and as a means of controlling rodent populations.

With TNVR, the cats can be good citizens that contribute to the control of GENUINE vermin. Please exclude ALL CATS from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA)'s definition of "vermin" in the agency's sanitation standard for Shipyard Employment.
label: pos
docAbstract: SIP IV is a rulemaking action intended to improve and streamline OSHA standards

text:
Feral Cats a.k.a. Community Cats, are not vermin. They are well cared for animals that prefer to live outside. Some can be socialized with time, perseverence and patience. I did this with an 8 year old un-neutered male that I trapped,neutered and vaccinated. It took 7 months of working with him to gain his trust and he is now part of our family of rescues.

Just because these cats aren't pets doesn't mean they're not cared for. Indeed, many shipyard employers and their employees value the cats both for companionship and as a means of controlling rodent populations.

Classifying shipyard cats as "vermin" will likely lead to their mistreatment and interfere with the trap-neuter-return (TNR) programs used to manage their numbers and keep the cats healthy.

OSHA is a very influential agency. By removing cats from the definition of "vermin," OSHA is setting an important example for other government agencies to establish policies that more effectively protect cats and promote public health and safety.

I ask you to please reconsider classifying shipyard cats as vermin.
label: pos
docAbstract: SIP IV is a rulemaking action intended to improve and streamline OSHA standards

text:
I am writing you to you regarding the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration's request for comments on Cybersecurity Best Practices for Modern Vehicles [Docket No. NHTSA-2016-0104] published on Oct. 28.

As a member of the American Motorcyclist Association-which represents motorcyclists who will share the road with vehicles using these technologies-safety is my utmost concern. Therefore, I support the NHTSA's recommendations to automobile manufacturers. Specifically, "Allocating dedicated resources within the organization focused on researching, investigating, implementing, testing, and validating product cybersecurity measures and vulnerabilities." (Emphasis added).

Since 2014, the AMA has been urging the U.S. Department of Transportation to test the security of vehicle-to-vehicle communications to ensure motorcyclists' safety and privacy. If this manual is adopted, it will help ensure that vehicles using advanced crash-avoidance and vehicle-to-vehicle technologies are not compromised. A threat the Federal Bureau of Investigation warns is a real risk.

The DOT reports that these advanced technologies will reduce the 6 million crashes and more than 30,000 deaths that occur on U.S. roadways annually. According to a National Telecommunication and Information Administration report-which was highlighted in an Intelligent Transportation Society of America letter to the Federal Communications Commission-connected-vehicle technology "will enhance safety on the nation's highways," potentially addressing "80 percent of the crash scenarios involving non-impaired drivers." The report also cites NHTSA research showing that connected-vehicle technology "could help prevent the majority of types of crashes that typically occur in the real world, such as crashes at intersections or while changing lanes."

In a landmark study titled Motorcycle Accident Cause Factors and Identification of Countermeasures Volume I: Technical Report, published in 1981 and commonly known as the "Hurt Report," the single most common multi-vehicle motorcycle crash involves a car making a left turn into the path of a motorcycle at an intersection. Additionally, in a "Motorcycle Accidents In-Depth Study," researchers investigated in detail 921 crashes in 1999 and 2000 in France, Germany, the Netherlands, Spain and Italy and learned, among other findings, that 54.3 percent of the crashes occurred at intersections.

With vehicular intersections already a well-documented problem for motorcyclists, can you imagine the danger presented by a false sense of security among drivers who rely too heavily on advanced safety technologies? Drivers may believe these technologies will fully protect them, as well as other road users, and may not be prepared should these technologies malfunction at a critical juncture.

This manual represents a sound first step in meeting a provision of the Fixing America's Surface Transportation Act (i.e., Highway Bill) relating to cybersecurity standards. It will help prevent hacking, spoofing and disruption of connected and automated transportation vehicles.

Thank you for the opportunity to provide comments on this important issue to motorcyclists.
label: pos
docAbstract: Agency Information Collection Activities; Cybersecurity Best Practices

As a member of the American Motorcyclist Association-which represents motorcyclists who will share the road with vehicles using these technologies-safety is my utmost concern. Therefore, I support the NHTSA's recommendations to automobile manufacturers. Specifically, "Allocating dedicated resources within the organization focused on researching, investigating, implementing, testing, and validating product cybersecurity measures and vulnerabilities." (Emphasis added).

Since 2014, the AMA has been urging the U.S. Department of Transportation to test the security of vehicle-to-vehicle communications to ensure motorcyclists' safety and privacy. If this manual is adopted, it will help ensure that vehicles using advanced crash-avoidance and vehicle-to-vehicle technologies are not compromised. A threat the Federal Bureau of Investigation warns is a real risk.

The DOT reports that these advanced technologies will reduce the 6 million crashes and more than 30,000 deaths that occur on U.S. roadways annually. According to a National Telecommunication and Information Administration report-which was highlighted in an Intelligent Transportation Society of America letter to the Federal Communications Commission-connected-vehicle technology "will enhance safety on the nation's highways," potentially addressing "80 percent of the crash scenarios involving non-impaired drivers." The report also cites NHTSA research showing that connected-vehicle technology "could help prevent the majority of types of crashes that typically occur in the real world, such as crashes at intersections or while changing lanes."

In a landmark study titled Motorcycle Accident Cause Factors and Identification of Countermeasures Volume I: Technical Report, published in 1981 and commonly known as the "Hurt Report," the single most common multi-vehicle motorcycle crash involves a car making a left turn into the path of a motorcycle at an intersection. Additionally, in a "Motorcycle Accidents In-Depth Study," researchers investigated in detail 921 crashes in 1999 and 2000 in France, Germany, the Netherlands, Spain and Italy and learned, among other findings, that 54.3 percent of the crashes occurred at intersections.

With vehicular intersections already a well-documented problem for motorcyclists, can you imagine the danger presented by a false sense of security among drivers who rely too heavily on advanced safety technologies? Drivers may believe these technologies will fully protect them, as well as other road users, and may not be prepared should these technologies malfunction at a critical juncture.

This manual represents a sound first step in meeting a provision of the Fixing America's Surface Transportation Act (i.e., Highway Bill) relating to cybersecurity standards. It will help prevent hacking, spoofing and disruption of connected and automated transportation vehicles.

Thank you for the opportunity to provide comments on this important issue to motorcyclists.
label: pos
docAbstract: Agency Information Collection Activities; Cybersecurity Best Practices

text:
"The moral test of government is how it treats those who are in the dawn of life, the children; those who are in the twilight of life, the aged; and those in the shadows of life, the sick, the needy and the handicapped." Hubert H. Humphrey

1. The proposed provision on eliminating the treating physician rule in the evaluation of medical evidence is an assault upon the integrity of the community of treating medical providers. Approving this rule would say in effect that treating physicians cannot be trusted to issue honest opinions regarding the functional abilities of their patients. Then the provision implies that physicians that are employees of the administration who have never treated the claimant, never seen the claimant and whose employment security is based in part upon how many claims they process in a workday and even how many claims they deny should be given more weight in their evaluations. This would lead the evaluation from a science-based methodology to a political/economic one based upon SSA's subjective determination of how many claimants they can afford to award benefits to each fiscal year.

The disability evaluation process has evolved into a labyrinthine scheme of enormous complexity involving archaic rituals and its own peculiar vernacular. It is already nearly incomprehensible to the claimant who is seeking to access his or her own money that was involuntarily taken from them every paycheck. Most hearing concludes with an examination of a vocational expert whose testimony is based upon the Dictionary of Occupational Titles, which has not been updated since 1991. For SSA to now declare that the opinion of the medical doctor who has been caring for the frequently multiple conditions that led to filing the application is not more important than a back-room SSA employee could seriously undermine public faith in the SSA.

2. The proposed rule revisions are contrary to Ninth Circuit law regarding the "credit-as-true" rule that provides that reviewing courts may affirm, modify, or reverse and remand with or without further administrative proceedings. 42 U.S.C. 405(g).

3. Further, regarding the "Articulation Rules" that allow the agency to ignore without explanation certain evidence, the Act itself provides that if the Commissioner's decision is unfavorable, it must contain a statement of the case, in understandable language, setting forth a discussion of the evidence, and stating the Commissioner's determination and the reason or reasons upon which it is based. 42 U.S.C. 404(a) (emphasis added). These proposed regulations are arguably at odds with the Social Security Act itself. If a claimant cannot tell how the Social Security judge made his or her decision, and the federal court cannot tell how the Social Security judge made the decision, how is there going to be any meaningful review of those decision, to ensure that they are correct?

4. The proposal to eliminate the need to give great weight to "Other Agencies' Decisions", especially the Veterans Administration is also misguided. When veterans are returning from combat with PTSD issues that are found by the VA to render them unemployable, it is confounding and contradictory to have Social Security then determine they are capable of full-time work. In fact, you should adopt a rule stating that when a Veteran is found 100% disabled by the VA, or found to be unemployable because of his or her service-connected disabilities (TDIU), they are presumed to be disabled under the Social Security system. This would not only promote uniformity across federal benefit systems, but it would encourage efficiency and ensure that disabled Veterans promptly receive the benefits they have earned.

5. I do support the revisions that would permit expansion of the definition of an "acceptable medical source". This is in line with the reality of the modern day that most physicians assistants and many nurse practitioners have their own caseloads and are most familiar with the patient.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: We propose to revise the Social Security and supplemental security income (SSI) disability regulations regarding sources of evidence for establishing the existence of a medically determinable impairment under title II and title XVI of the Social Security Act (the Act).  The proposed change would expand the current list of acceptable medical sources to include nurse practitioners, physician assistants, licensed clinical social workers, and audiologists. This change would allow us to use the evidence from these sources to establish a claimant’s medically determinable impairment(s).

text:
Docket No. FDA-1988-N00880
Sunlamp Products" Proposed Amendment to Performance Standard

As an indoor tanning client who uses sunbeds in a professional salon, I strongly oppose the FDA's proposal to limit my indoor tanning sessions. I am well aware of the risks of UV overexposure, as is virtually everyone in America today. This topic gets more coverage than almost any other health issue.

I am also aware the the World Health Organization in 2015 placed bacon on the list of Level 1 carcinogens in the same category as a sunbed. WHO and the governments response to bacon's listing as a carcinogen was simply to warn people to use common sense and exercise judgement. The government did NOT step in and limit bacon consumption.

To my knowledge, there is no precedent where the federal government has put limits on consumer consumption for anything including alcohol and tobacco. Since indoor tanning carries a much smaller health risk than tobacco, how can limits in indoor tanning be justified?

Please work with the indoor tanning industry to develop standards that help prevent sunburn, but do no limit my ability, properly advised, to make choices about UV exposure in a professional salon for me or for any member of my family.

Additionally, I believe there are many BENEFITS to indoor tanning. I personally burn VERY easy, even with a high SPF Sunblock. Indoor tanning allows me to slowly prepare my skin and avoid painful and dangerous burns. Additionally, it helps with many skin conditions such as acne. Also, living in a state where our winters are rather harsh, I depend on the these establishments to enhance my overall mood. DO NOT take away our rights as citizens.

Sincerely,

Jessica Holden

text:
Docket No. FDA-1998-N0880

Sunlamp Products: Proposed Amendment to Performance Standard

As the owner of a professional tanning facility, I am submitting these comments in conjunction with material provided by the American Suntanning Association. I am concerned that, based on my experience, many of these proposals as written will not reduce sunburn incidence nor optimize exposure levels for my clients. Specifically:

FDA 21CFR 1040.20(d)(1)(iv) introduces an entirely new approach for a Manufacturer-Recommended Exposure Schedule. I have several concerns with this:

(1) FDA's proposed "Manufacturer-Recommended Exposure Schedule" needs revision. This system is supposed to provide a recommend framework leading to an absolute maximum time (the Maximum Timer Interval) to incrementally expose a tanner gradually. I could not in good faith recommend the series of intervals FDA proposes to my clients, which call for 3-4 minute increases from one session to the next - larger incremental increases than what I would ever routinely allow a client and for which FDA has no data in an actual salon tanning unit.

(2) Eliminating skin types from the schedule is a mistake. FDA asserts, "Skin Type III and IV can attain a tan with UV doses that are similar to what is needed for Skin Type II" based on a small study done with non-salon equipment in FDA's lab (Miller et al, 2012). While FDA's effort appears to be in good faith, based on my professional experience with thousands of tanning clients, FDA's conclusion is false. FDA did not even test Type IV tanners in its study. What's more, teaching clients their Fitzpatrick Skin Type is critical in my business to teach clients how to prevent sunburn both in the salon and outdoors. For clients with Skin Type II it may take several sessions before they see any results (which FDA expressed it wants clients to understand, per proposed 1040.20(5)(D)5). Taking this tool away will hurt my ability to teach Skin Type II sunbed clients how to prevent sunburn.

(3) Tanning courses and session frequency recommendations need revision. FDA's introduction of a "tanning course" ("the period of time over which a tan is developed" which FDA says is typically 3-4 weeks) and the suggestion that two sessions weekly should be a maximum fails to take into account why and how most indoor tanning clients visit salons and how professional salons teach and achieve sunburn prevention.

(a) A client who establishes a tan and then maintains it would not be engaging in a new "course." Almost no client starts, stops and starts tanning as a "course" six times in a year. Most tan about three sessions a week for four weeks, and then maintain their tan with differing frequency based on their skin type.

(b) Limiting a client to two sessions weekly will result in clients visiting more than one salon to get 3-4 sessions weekly or simply purchasing home tanning units, which FDA knows are associated with greater sunburn risk, both of which would increase variables between exposures and increase sunburn. It will also lead to clients requesting longer exposure times to compensate for having fewer visits, which is counterproductive to teaching gradual exposure and sunburn prevention.

(c) Instead of recommending 48 hours between sessions on the label, I suggest this recommendation: "Allow 24-48 hours between sessions to prevent sunburn." That gives the sunbed user and a salon operator the information they need to properly space sessions to prevent sunburn.

(d) Recommending a maximum of 48-50 sessions (15kJ) per year isn't warranted. There is no real metric for how you have established this. The government does not limit bacon or tobacco consumption for those who choose to consume those products - both of which present larger risks than sunbeds. I suggest the following: A statement on the exposure schedule that says, "Limit Your Total Exposure. UV overexposure is linked to skin cancer."

(4) FDA should not require salons to recertify equipment currently in the marketplace to comply with the new Performance Standard. This would be more costly than FDA estimates and would likely shutter my business.

Without the changes I have suggested, the combined economic impact of FDA's proposals as written would not prevent sunburn nor reduce exposure, but would eliminate more than 40 percent of my salon's total revenue and would not educate clients in an effective fashion. Combined with FDA Rule FDA-2015-N01765, these rules would eliminate 47-50 percent of my salon's revenue - WHICH WOULD CLOSE MY BUSINESS.

Please allow the American Suntanning Association and industry suppliers to work with you to improve your proposals.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: Docket Status: OPEN

label: neut
docAbstract:
Pursuant to sections 1031 and 1032 of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Public Law 111-203) (Dodd-Frank Act), the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (Bureau) is proposing to establish 12 CFR part 1041, which would contain regulations creating consumer protections for certain consumer credit products. The proposal generally would cover two categories of loans. First, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term of 45 days or less or loans with multiple advances if each advance is required to be repaid within 45 days. Second, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term greater than 45 days, provided that they (1) have an all-in annual percentage rate greater than 36 percent; and (2) either are repaid directly from the consumer’s account or income or are secured by the consumer’s vehicle. For both categories of covered loans, the proposal would identify it as an abusive and unfair practice for a lender to make a covered loan without reasonably determining that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal generally would require that, before making a covered loan, a lender must reasonably determine that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal also would impose certain restrictions on making covered loans when a consumer has or recently had certain an outstanding covered loan. The proposal would provide lenders with options to make covered loans without satisfying the ability-to-repay requirements, if those loans meet certain conditions. The proposal also would identify it as an unfair and abusive practice to attempt to withdraw payment from a consumer’s account for a
covered loan after two consecutive payment attempts have failed. The proposal would require lenders to provide certain notices to the consumer before attempting to withdraw payment for a
covered loan from the consumer’s account. The Bureau is also proposing to adopt official interpretations to the proposed regulation.

Pursuant to sections 1031 and 1032 of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Public Law 111-203) (Dodd-Frank Act), the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (Bureau) is proposing to establish 12 CFR part 1041, which would contain regulations creating consumer protections for certain consumer credit products. The proposal generally would cover two categories of loans. First, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term of 45 days or less or loans with multiple advances if each advance is required to be repaid within 45 days. Second, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term greater than 45 days, provided that they (1) have an all-in annual percentage rate greater than 36 percent; and (2) either are repaid directly from the consumer’s account or income or are secured by the consumer’s vehicle. For both categories of covered loans, the proposal would identify it as an abusive and unfair practice for a lender to make a covered loan without reasonably determining that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal generally would require that, before making a covered loan, a lender must reasonably determine that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal also would impose certain restrictions on making covered loans when a consumer has or recently had certain an outstanding covered loan. The proposal would provide lenders with options to make covered loans without satisfying the ability-to-repay requirements, if those loans meet certain conditions. The proposal also would identify it as an unfair and abusive practice to attempt to withdraw payment from a consumer’s account for a
covered loan after two consecutive payment attempts have failed. The proposal would require lenders to provide certain notices to the consumer before attempting to withdraw payment for a
covered loan from the consumer’s account. The Bureau is also proposing to adopt official interpretations to the proposed regulation.

The severity of my pain often causes me to miss work as well as limiting normal daily activities I can do with my 4 year old son. My spine specialist had prescribed me hydrocodone for the last 2 years in order to take the edge off of the pain...I suffered with this severe pain for years while trying to avoid having to resort to taking pain medication due to the risks that come along with it. I would only take my medication when I desperately needed it to avoid becoming dependent. I finally starting researching the internet about natural ways to control severe pain out of desperation to completely discontinue the use of pain medication and also find some sort of effective relief from this constant pain, which is when I came across Kratom. I read every article and piece of research I could find on this plant and decided to order a few samples from an online Kratom distribution store. I mixed half of a teaspoon with some juice and within half an hour my back pain was completely gone. Aside from the biggest feeling of relief I'd felt in years, the best part about this was the fact that I felt completely normal! I had zero side effects and my mind nor body felt altered in any way shape or form. Since then I've been continuing the use of Kratom, taking about 1/2-1 teaspoon in the morning just a few times a week and I have completely discontinued the use of pain medication. I honestly feel like Kratom could change the life of many chronic pain sufferers and greatly decrease the need for narcotic pain medication. I hope that you see the amazing benefits this plant could have in the world of chronic pain sufferers and really weigh out the benefits of keeping this substance legal. Thank you for taking the time to hear my story out and for your consideration.

text:
The Datz Foundation, a Hague-accredited adoption service provider, makes the following comments on the proposed regulations concerning intercountry adoption (Billing Code 4710-06, Department of State, 22CFR Part 96, RIN 1400-AD91)

Country Specific Authorizations

1.The requirement for an adoption service provider to obtain a Country Specific Authorization (CSA) represents a hardship on United States Citizens proposing to adopt relatives. This demographic comprises families and individuals of limited financial means. Additional fees necessitated by using a primary provider with CSA would be an unfair burden on them and would have a chilling effect on adoption.
2.Larger agencies will have the financial wherewithal to pay whatever fee(s) are required to attain authorization; smaller agencies will not. As a corollary, there is a risk that one or two agencies will be granted a monopoly in a sending country.
3.The CSA procedure represents yet another unnecessary hurdle and layer of bureaucracy and regulation in a process that is already heavily burdened by bureaucracy and regulation.

Additional Training

Prospective adoptive parents are already required to take ten hours of training, much of it oriented toward intercountry adoption. This is sufficient. No amount of training will prevent unauthorized custody transfers, which are statistically insignificant compared with the thousands of successful intercountry placements which occur annually.

Foreign Supervised Providers

Adoption Service Providers do not have the ability to "supervise" foreign adoption professionals and entities. Indeed, the concept smacks of interference and neo-imperialism. Consider the reverse: A U.S-based attorney providing adoption services would doubtless balk at being "supervised" by a foreign entity.

Compensation of Individuals and Entities in Sending Country

It should not be the role of the Department of State to determine "reasonable" compensation in a sending country. Consider again the reverse: A foreign consulate in Washington DC tries to determine "reasonable" legal fees of American adoption professionals or placement fees of adoption service providers. Fees and compensation must be determined by the free market.

Submission of Complaints

The proposed rule would allow aggrieved clients to file a complaint directly with the Complaint Registry "for action by the accrediting entity". This contradicts generally accepted principles of conflict resolution. Our objections are the following:

1.An aggrieved party should first present its grievance to the provider. In many cases, a resolution can be reached without recourse to further complaints. If no resolution can be reached, recourse to the Complaint Registry is appropriate.
2.The accrediting entity's staff and resources would be burdened by frivolous complaints which could easily have been resolved by the adoption service provider.
3.The suggestion that a provider might "retaliate" against a complainant is offensive and imputes an ill will to adoption service providers which have previously been thoroughly vetted by the accrediting entity in order to achieve accreditation.

In short, The Datz Foundation opposes the proposed regulations and views them as an attempt, intended or unintended, to reduce further the number of intercountry adoptions.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: The Department of State (the Department) proposes to amend requirements for accreditation of agencies and approval of persons to provide adoption services in intercountry adoption cases.  The proposed rule includes a new subpart establishing parameters for U.S. accrediting entities to authorize adoption service providers who  have received accreditation or approval to provide adoption services in countries designated by the Secretary which will be known as “country-specific authorization” (CSA).   Adoption service providers will only be permitted to act as primary providers in a CSA-designated country if they have received CSA for that particular country.  The proposed rule also strengthens certain standards for accreditation and approval including those related to fees and the use of foreign providers.  In addition, the proposed rule enhances standards relating to preparation of prospective adoptive parents so that they receive more training related to the most common challenges faced by adoptive families, and are better prepared for the needs of the specific child they are adopting.  These proposed changes are intended to align the preparation of prospective adoptive parents with the current demographics of children immigrating to the United States through intercountry adoption.   Finally, the proposed rule makes the mechanism to submit complaints about adoption service providers available to complainants even if they have not first addressed their complaint directly with the adoption service provider.

text:
Feral cats (actually community cats) are NOT vermin. They are simply cats who don't necessarily trust people. Many of the cats are valued for their companionship and their ability to keep the rat population down.

Please stop classifying these cats as vermin.
label: pos
docAbstract: SIP IV is a rulemaking action intended to improve and streamline OSHA standards

text:
I am in favor of supporting a change to Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) rules to no longer include
"feral cats" under its definition of "vermin" in the agency's sanitation standard for Shipyard Employment.

Just because these cats aren't pets doesn't mean they're not cared for. Indeed, many shipyard employers and their
employees value the cats both for companionship and as a means of controlling rodent populations.
Classifying shipyard cats as "vermin" will likely lead to their mistreatment and interfere with the trap-neuter-return (TNR)
programs used to manage their numbers and keep the cats healthy.
OSHA is a very influential agency. By removing cats from the definition of "vermin," OSHA is setting an important example
for other government agencies to establish policies that more effectively protect cats and promote public health and safety

Please be a leader and support and value feral cats and support TNR as well as managed colonies where TNR exists.
This is what the public is in favor of as well.

text:
1. Country Specific Authorization: I think that when an agency has Hague Accreditation that should suffice. In our experience they should add more accredited agencies that can work with all the states in the United States and that are acceptable to the local authority from the country of origin and increase the annual caps. In the state we live there were no agencies listed in the State Department page, as such we had to hire another agency that could work with the one on their list and that created layers to the bureaucracy already embeded in the process. The agencies on the list should be able to handle the whole process regardless the state of residency of the prospective adoptive parents. Simple is better and more efficient!
2. Change Education Requirements: I think the participation in a foster care training is outrageous. In normal life when women are pregnant they do not receive any kind of psychological or experimental training to raise kids. They just receive health related care and updates on the stages and necessary information from professional sources, if they are lucky to have access to that. Remember that adoption is an act of love and I do not consider necessary that you need to play the foster parent role to be fitted. Remember that the longer the waiting to fulfilled unmet needs for the children, the more damaging it is for them than for the prospective parents.
3. Child Care Fees Disallowed: Definitely not! The child care fees are fundamental for the basic necessites of the children in the orphanage or creche. I consider that prospective adopting parents should be allowed to pay for those costs directly to the orphanage or creche. Agencies can control that payments occur timely, but they should not handle them.
4. Cost to Adoption Providers: I do not agree that you need to add insurance to the cost of inter-country adoption. Regulation should be drafted to include aid from international organizations to increase the efficiency and institutional capacity of the local ministries and agencies involved in the country of origin of the adoption. Timeline of the whole process should be significantly reduced. Bureaucracy is too big on both ends. Add technology to the process, too much papers are needed in print!

text:
Thank you for reconsidering your decision to schedule kratom without public comment. I have read through a number of comments. While aren't many studies that confirm the anecdotal evidence in these comments, I hope that the 1000s of people who have shared their story give regulators pause when considering scheduling kratom.

I have never used kratom, but my wife used it successfully to treat chronic pain. We're a young family. I'm 33, my wife 32, and our daughter 2. With the exception of this year, my wife had slowly deteriorated physically and mentally from chronic pain for the last number of years. She saw her primary care doctor countless times along with regular visits to the rheumatologist and other specialists.

Under the care of her doctors, she slowly but surely was prescribed a larger and larger batter of pharmaceutical medications. Sometimes, the pain would temporarily subside but mostly it stayed the same or progressed. Her mental condition was the most difficult for her and to see. Towards the end of using Lyrica, Abilify, Xanax, and a handful of other medications that I can't remember, she became agoraphobic. Her condition was wrongly thought to be progressing and was told to see a neurologist and get an EMG.

In truth, she was experiencing side effects from medications and then put on additional medications to address the side effects. It was a vicious circle that increased her anxiety substantially and, looking back, likely caused a psychosomatic increase in pain.

I kept looking for answers because I was losing my wife and was drowning in the pressure of being a caregiver to my baby, my wife, and as the sole breadwinner. Occasionally, my wife would be open to trying alternative treatments. One of them was kratom. We were thoughtful about her approach to using kratom including it's dose, what strains to use and when, and so on. Kratom is most effective in small amounts and kratom has a natural way of preventing you from taking it in large amounts, nausea and taste!

Are there people misusing kratom, surely. The people who are misusing kratom are mixing with it opioids and other drugs. Just as surely as people are misusing kratom, they aren't dying from it. They are dying from fentanyl, heroin, etc. and happen to have kratom in their system at the time.

Do people who use kratom often continue to use it for potentially indefinite periods of time, yes. There are counter examples though. My wife used kratom for a short period and the relief allowed her to the opportunity to get off all of her prescriptions medications. Kratom gave me my wife back. Her pain levels reduced substantially from her improved mental state and with some subsequent dietary changes her pain has subsided.

As to the people who depend upon kratom. It's important to point out something that you already know, that dependence and addiction are two different things. You and I are dependent upon water. We don't, however, exhibit the kind of behaviors of substance use disorder such as physically risky behaviors, isolating ourselves from important relationships, etc. Just as some people are on SSRIs indefinitely, some kratom users are too because they need the results that it produces.

Users of this herbal supplement can keep their tolerance low by changing the strains that they use regularly, an occasional off day, and other methods.

In short, kratom doesn't meet the definition of a schedule 1 drug. It has medicinal value and it's addiction potential is low.

My wife's experience with kratom and my own with chiropractic care, has led me to believe that regulatory agencies should to take an extremely conservative approach in regulating alternative health. This is my body and I'm responsible for what I put it in it with some notable exceptions that endanger public health, eg. heroin, cocaine, etc. Kratom is a natural substance and with care can be a helpful supplement to many.

I'm sure that there are people using all kinds of herbs irresponsibly thought not necessarily recreationally. I read a story about someone who slathered neem, used to clean teeth in some forms among other uses, all over his teeth and gums leaving it there for 20 minutes. At that point, he was desperately posting on an alternative health forum because the skin on his gums was peeling. I'm sure he ended up fine, and hopefully he learned that he is responsible for his health and it's a sacred responsibility that should be pursued with thought and care.

I ask that you not schedule kratom since it does not meet the criteria for a schedule one drug and that, generally speaking, you allow people to take responsibility for their own health as they see fit.

text:
Department of Transportation (DOT)
Docket # DOT-OST-2016-0208
RIN 2105-AE53

To Whom It May Concern:

According to the August 2016 AIR TRAVEL CONSUMER REPORT, mishandled baggage reports filed by 12 US Airlines, totals to 175,365 mishandled bags for that month alone. In other data from the Department's Bureau of Transportation Statistics (BTS), the top 13 U.S. carriers collectively generated over $3.8 billion in revenue in 2015 from baggage fees. If the DOT is trying to determine the appropriate length of delay within the statutory parameters that would trigger the refund requirement, this data alone should assist in making that decision. I understand in the past the airlines were facing high oil prices and low profits, but according to the data, that does not seem to be the case any more. If they are able to generate that much income from baggage fees alone, I see no reasons as to why they can't invest some of that profit to improve the baggage handling system. As for promptly providing an automated refund for any ancillary fees paid by the passenger for checked baggage. I believe if the baggage does not arrive with the passenger at the time of arrival, the fees charged should be refunded and the baggage delivered within the time frame provided by The Act. If this is not possible, than the refund should be issued to passengers if the carrier fails to deliver the checked baggage to the passenger not later than 12 hours after the arrival of a domestic flight, or not later than 15 hours after the arrival of an international flight. There should not be any extension of the timeframe, which I believe will motivate the airlines to invest in creating a system that can better process baggages. Now, having said that, I understand that the airlines are not the only factors in mishandled baggage. For that reason, I believe The Act should also allow the airlines to investigate and get reimbursement, if the airport or Transportation Security Administration (TSA) is at fault. Also, if the passenger checked-in later than the time frame required by the airlines, than the refund should be void, because sufficient time was not provided to process the baggage. As far as international flights, they should be considered the same as domestics. The reason being, a standard interline connection on a single ticket can make the process easier for the passenger, but in the case of a connection constructed by the passenger using two tickets can have a major impact on the travel experience. At the end of the day, the goal is to create a better experience for the passenger and not to make the airlines jobs easier.

Thank you for your consideration of my comment.

Pursuant to sections 1031 and 1032 of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (Public Law 111-203) (Dodd-Frank Act), the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (Bureau) is proposing to establish 12 CFR part 1041, which would contain regulations creating consumer protections for certain consumer credit products. The proposal generally would cover two categories of loans. First, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term of 45 days or less or loans with multiple advances if each advance is required to be repaid within 45 days. Second, the proposal generally would cover loans with a term greater than 45 days, provided that they (1) have an all-in annual percentage rate greater than 36 percent; and (2) either are repaid directly from the consumer’s account or income or are secured by the consumer’s vehicle. For both categories of covered loans, the proposal would identify it as an abusive and unfair practice for a lender to make a covered loan without reasonably determining that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal generally would require that, before making a covered loan, a lender must reasonably determine that the consumer has the ability to repay the loan. The proposal also would impose certain restrictions on making covered loans when a consumer has or recently had certain an outstanding covered loan. The proposal would provide lenders with options to make covered loans without satisfying the ability-to-repay requirements, if those loans meet certain conditions. The proposal also would identify it as an unfair and abusive practice to attempt to withdraw payment from a consumer’s account for a
covered loan after two consecutive payment attempts have failed. The proposal would require lenders to provide certain notices to the consumer before attempting to withdraw payment for a
covered loan from the consumer’s account. The Bureau is also proposing to adopt official interpretations to the proposed regulation.

text:
-------
Docket No. FDA-2015-N-1765
As an employee at a professional suntanning salon, I would like to encourage FDA to work with the American Suntanning Association to revise its proposed regulations. These proposed rules will lead to an increase in sunburn and skin damage if implemented as written. The American Suntanning Association has requested, constructively, to work with FDA to fix these issues. Specifically:
- FDA-1998-N-0880 introduces an entirely new approach for sunbed exposure schedules. This new system eliminates the world standard skin typing system that we use to help prevent clients from overexposure. Further, I could not in good faith recommend the new series of intervals FDA proposes for my clients, which call for 3-4 minute increases from one session to the next - larger incremental increases than I would routinely allow many of my clients and for which FDA has no data in an actual salon tanning unit.
- FDA-1998-0880 arbitrarily limits my clients to 48 tanning sessions a year and just two sessions weekly. There is no science to support this blanket proposal. More importantly, there is no precedent for the federal government limiting consumer choice for any legal product - fast food hamburgers, bacon or even tobacco, all of which are on the World Health Organization's List of Carcinogens.
- FDA-2015-N-1765 would require my clients to sign a consent form every six months instead of simply once. Requiring this to be done every six months would be an administrative nightmare, without serving any valid public purpose. There is no other product or service in the country, including the purchase of alcohol, tobacco and red meat that requires consumers to sign such a form. It would be unfair to require this for our business and not for the hundreds of products and services that present many more dangers than UV exposure.
- FDA-2015-N-1765 also imposes a federal ban on UV tanning for those under age 18. If minors are prohibited from using indoor tanning salons, they will instead use sunbeds at home, in an unregulated and unsupervised environment, and likely tan more aggressively outdoors. These alternatives would lead to an increase in sunburn and injury, compared to tanning at our salons that enforce tan time limits and other safety precautions.

text:
Docket No. FDA-2015-N-1765

As an employee at a professional suntanning salon, I would like to encourage FDA to work with the American Suntanning Association to revise its proposed regulations. These proposed rules will lead to an increase in sunburn and skin damage if implemented as written. The American Suntanning Association has requested, constructively, to work with FDA to fix these issues. Specifically:

- FDA-1998-N-0880 introduces an entirely new approach for sunbed exposure schedules. This new system eliminates the world standard skin typing system that we use to help prevent clients from overexposure. Further, I could not in good faith recommend the new series of intervals FDA proposes for my clients, which call for 3-4 minute increases from one session to the next - larger incremental increases than I would routinely allow many of my clients and for which FDA has no data in an actual salon tanning unit.

- FDA-1998-0880 arbitrarily limits my clients to 48 tanning sessions a year and just two sessions weekly. There is no science to support this blanket proposal. More importantly, there is no precedent for the federal government limiting consumer choice for any legal product - fast food hamburgers, bacon or even tobacco, all of which are on the World Health Organization's List of Carcinogens.

- FDA-2015-N-1765 would require my clients to sign a consent form every six months instead of simply once. Requiring this to be done every six months would be an administrative nightmare, without serving any valid public purpose. There is no other product or service in the country, including the purchase of alcohol, tobacco and red meat that requires consumers to sign such a form. It would be unfair to require this for our business and not for the hundreds of products and services that present many more dangers than UV exposure.

- FDA-2015-N-1765 also imposes a federal ban on UV tanning for those under age 18. If minors are prohibited from using indoor tanning salons, they will instead use sunbeds at home, in an unregulated and unsupervised environment, and likely tan more aggressively outdoors. These alternatives would lead to an increase in sunburn and injury, compared to tanning at our salons that enforce tan time limits and other safety precautions.

Please allow the American Suntanning Association and industry suppliers to work with you to improve your proposals.

docAbstract:
Congress established the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection (Bureau or CFPB) in the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act of 2010 (Dodd-Frank Act). As set forth in section 1021
of the Dodd-Frank Act, the Bureau’s purpose is to implement and, where
applicable, enforce Federal consumer financial law consistently for the
purpose of ensuring that all consumers have access to markets for consumer financial products and services and that markets for consumer financial products and services are fair, transparent, and competitive. In discharging this obligation, the CFPB seeks feedback on practices and products that are related to but may not be addressed in the Bureau’s concurrently published Notice of Proposed Rulemaking on Payday,
Vehicle Title, and Certain High-Cost Installment Loans (Concurrent
Proposal). Specifically, in this Request for Information (RFI), the Bureau seeks comment on: Potential consumer protection concerns with loans that fall outside the scope of the Bureau’s Concurrent Proposal but are designed to serve similar populations and needs as those loans covered by the proposal; and business practices concerning loans falling within the Bureau’s Concurrent Proposal’s coverage that raise potential consumer protection concerns that are not addressed by the Concurrent
Proposal. The Bureau seeks comment from the public about these consumer lending practices to increase the Bureau’s understanding of and support for potential future efforts, including but not limited to future rulemakings, supervision, enforcement, or consumer education initiatives. Where the Bureau requests evidence, data, or other information regarding a particularly concern about consumer protections, the Bureau does not seek information that directly identifies an individual consumer.
